review.title: Learning to Partition using Score Based Compatibilities
review.abstract: We study the problem of learning to partition users into groups, where one must learn the compatibilities between the users to achieve optimal groupings. We define four natural objectives that optimize for average and worst case compatibilities and propose new algorithms for adaptively learning optimal groupings. When we do not impose any structure on the compatibilities, we show that the group formation objectives considered are $NP$ hard to solve and we either give approximation guarantees or prove inapproximability results. We then introduce an elegant structure, namely that of \textit{intrinsic scores}, that makes many of these problems polynomial time solvable. We explicitly characterize the optimal groupings under this structure and show that the optimal solutions are related to \emph{homophilous} and \emph{heterophilous} partitions, well-studied in the psychology literature. For one of the four objectives, we show $NP$ hardness under the score structure and give a $\frac{1}{2}$ approximation algorithm for which no constant approximation was known thus far. Finally, under the score structure, we propose an online low sample complexity PAC algorithm for learning the optimal partition. We demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed algorithm on synthetic and real world datasets.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments
sections.text: We evaluate the quality of the LearnOrder algorithm using simulated and real data. The graph examples we selected were the following: (a) Random: For this synthetically generated data set, we set the group size k = 4 and the chart size n = 16. We added a uniform noise between [− 1, 1] to the feedback in each round, and the score for each element was drawn uniformly randomly from {1,..., 10}. And (b) Social network: A 16-node instance was sampled from the Facebook friendship graph, which was built from an existing anonymized data set of Facebook users "data (Leskovec and Krevl 2014). The data set has 4039 user nodes and 88234 unweighted edges. We used the Jaccard similarity coefficient of characteristics such as education, hometown, language, etc., to obtain values for users that are inconsistent.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: We investigated the problem of grouping a group of users using their pairwise compatibilities. However, we first showed hardness and approximation when no assumptions are made about the pairwise compatibility values. Then, we examined the intrinsic score model for compatibility, which is not only simple and direct, but also very similar to the popular Bradley-Terry-Luce (BTL) model for pairwise comparisons. Within this model, we linked the optimal grouping with homophilic and heterophilic groupings, which are well studied in the psychological literature. We proposed the LearnOrder algorithm, which, after selecting a small number of groups, learns adaptively the best order corresponding to the score vector of the pairwise compatibility matrix. Our experiments on both synthetic and real data sets demonstrate the effectiveness of our algorithm.
